header.title: Gypsy Travellers: A Life On The Run
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: SUBSCRIBE HERE: http://bit.ly/2ol5mam  . . For generations groups of travellers have spent their lives on the move, invading public parks and illegally squatting at the end of your road. . . They have been branded a public menace. But do travellers have the right to travel? Or is this the end of the road for their traditional way of life?. . . Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/NKDStories/ . . Clip from My Big Fat Gypsy Wedding, 2016. Content licensed from Firecracker Films. For any enquiries, please contact us at info@passiondistribution.com

commentThread.commentText: Just because you were raise different don't mean you have to discriminate. Gypsys are people as are gorgers so just show some respect will ye, not every gypsy is bad

I see so many offensive comments towards travelers. You ever heard the saying don't stroke every folk with the same brush. I come from a travelling family myself, to understand the culture, the real culture. You never will. Non of you are open minded which is why true travelers stay private and away from house people ‘gorgers'. It's trying to keep up old traditions. Which stems from respecting the life style your grandparents lived. I, myself and my siblings have been brought up in a house for many years now and have gone to school, college. And work. The old traditions won't stay alive much longer because everything's moving up in life. However have you ever sat and thought to yourself that if we move into a house and live the life you will, you still won't accept us. It's taken many years for us to be accepted in our neighbor hoods. We had so many hate crimes happen, me a young 12 yea r old having drunk women try and attack me because I'm a ‘smel ly gypsy girl'. And you wonder why we want to fuck off and live our own peaceful lives. Because we don't get judged. We had to put up with so much. Just so my 11 y ear old sister and young cousins can live a peaceful life and go to school. I have to withhold the abuse so eventually you all give up and give the younger generations a chance. I'm 19 now. I smile and say hello to my now neighbours who used to hurl abuse to me, a young child at the ages of 15. Have you ever thought about the effects this had on me, wondering why I didn't want to go to school. I was riddled with anxiety and didn't want to leave my home. The bullying never stopped until I left high school and went to a college. I will say this, my family never once started trouble but we finished it and defended ourselves. My great grandad was a well respected man, who didn't believe in thieving or lying. Strong catholics at that. And because you all seen something on tv you presumed we was like what you seen on tv. Now, imagine if this was any religion or other culture put through this. You'd stand up and defend them. But us gypsys get no one defending us all our lives we will have to defend ourselves.

commentThread.commentText: The kids are horrible show no respect at all all

I've always tought my sons to treat people how they want to be treated. Last night I was walking with two of my sons to fetch a 3rd from cubs, on the way two 'travellers' tried to humiliate me by calling into question whether or not I was the owner of two functioning testicles. To be honest, I was confused at first, as I presummed by their voices that they were suffering some speech, and or, mental malady. They took my apparent confusion as a win, and sauntered off to intimidate the staff at the local shop. My kids were full of questions! Suffice to say I simply told them that travellers are a proud and noble race who felt so threatened by our walking past them, that they had to strike first. I then reiterated that diversity is our strength, and that our ancestors probably enslaved their ancestors, so really, it's all we deserve. My kids asked why I didn't stick up for myself, a difficult one that, I just went with the truth, and said, "The noble travellers love to fight people, any people, as its part of their rich and diverse culture. However, if I defended myself verbally, then they would see that as a green light from me that I wanted to partake in a fight. Then, if the one I started to fight with looked to be in any way losing, his companion would then feel compelled to join in, to guarantee my defeat. He may also call his nearby relatives, and they would also feel that it would be in everyone's best interest for them to ensure that I spent the next few days in hospital". So suffice to say, I'm sure there are some travellers who are great, unfortunately I've yet to meet one, or indeed, anyone who has had a positive experience with one. This programme virtually celebrates their existence, each syllable dripping with patronising admiration.

commentThread.commentText: Actually had 1 good experience with travellers, although I know that it's an exception. They got onto my land (my dad owned a little farm for a few years before he got tired of the early mornings) and set up camp overnight. We had a broken fence at the end of the path between the field and our house. They fixed it overnight, we didn't even ask. They then came to apologise, and told us that they'd just been evicted, had only a few people (there were about 4 or 5 caravans) and they needed somewhere to go until they found a place more permanent (in their terms, a week or 2). We told them they could stay for up to a week, as long as they took all litter and didn't leave any trace of being here and didn't try to do anything dodgy. They left after a week and the place was spotless. Rare, but cool
If one of them is sick they go to a hospital. If they need food they get social welfare. You get the benefits of a 21st century western world, now welcome to following it's laws.

commentThread.commentText: I understand that travellers do sometimes cause problems such as dumping waste and trespassing on private land when stationed illegally, however there is a wider issue that concerns me. During world war 2 the Nazis killed millions in the death camps, but what we seem to forget is that a significant proportion of them were gypsies. The ideology that the Nazis embellished, that they were in some way superior to travellers, amongst other groups, seems to still exist today, even in a reduced form. At the end of the day travellers are no different from any other person, and should not be marginalised for their way of life, as that is not our place to judge. As I said, a minority may cause some trouble, but what we seem to forget is that many of the non-traveller community are very difficult in their behaviour towards the wider public also. Although many of us may have formed opinions, some with basis, some without, it is important to remember that travellers are humans of the same importance as the rest of us and that their culture should be respected and treated with as much dignity as any other. Not all people are the same, we should not generalise a specific culture on our opinions or isolated events as this breeds unnecessary hatred.

To be fair, it's not always been like that. Because travellers don't want to integrate into mainstream society they have always been demonised and disrespected. It's no wonder communities turn militant when no matter where they go they are discriminated against and judged to be all the same. Any minority throughout history has had to endure untold amounts of suffering until society finally accepted them. It's easy to pretend like certain people don't belong and are alien to society because it makes you feel better about yourself but your identity and your way of life is just as subjective and fragile as anyone else's, including travelers. You could lose your home tomorrow, you could be thrown on the streets, lose your job, be patronised by your peers and excluded from your community. Who says you should be treated like that? If that's true why should anyone else? You get the bad people wherever you go and whoever those people are. Doesn't mean everybody is the same. My ex girlfriend was a settled Irish traveller and she was the nices t woman I had met. She's married now. Her dad has worked all his life. Her mum too. Her family are very well connected. But if you think they've had that life given to them on a plate think again. She used to tell me how people would throw them out of pubs for belonging to the Iri sh traveller community, without doing anything wrong! She would get dirty looks walking down the street and got bullied at school for being different. She chose to stick with education and came out with a degree despite most women in the community feeling pressured to follow the traditional path. She never said boo to a goose and her family never caused any trouble. Not to say an extended members didn't but you find me an extended family that is squeaky clean and model citizens. It's all relative and your stats are bullshit. Provide evidence or fuck off.

Never mind whether it's civil or criminal in the UK - at its essence, trespassing is theft.  Whether for an hour, a day, a week, a month or indefinitely, trespassers are using something that doesn't belong to them, without permission.  

I can't fit my work vehicle in my driveway, and I can't park it in the street in the winter months.  So I pay a local restauranteur to park it in his lot.  If I didn't ask first, and pay him, he could have it towed.  Then I would have to pay the towing company to get it back.  And it would be only right for my being there uninvited.

And if there isn't somewhere to park it, that's nobody's problem but my own, the fact that I have a large vehicle doesn't mean I have an automatic right to park it somewhere.
Don't you think about how that makes kids feel? I am a gypsy kid and that will hurt my feelings I am 11. And you have made me cry. Think before you do.

I've tried not to be nasty and have avoided mentioning Travellers by name - trespassing is a problem that transcends the experience of travellers and the settled community with which they interact.  

I live across the Atlantic and have never encountered an illegal encampment.  Also, I travel for a living, running freight back and forth between Canada and the US.  I spent most of last week between New York City and Toronto.  Texas the week before.  Don't actually remember the week before that. When not running, I park and sleep where I might.  Alone.  When asked to leave, I do so.  Immediately.  Or, I go home.

My family does not come with me.  My wife and kids stay in the house that I bought, maintain, and on which I pay taxes.  I want them to feel safe and secure where they sleep.  That feeling is best achieved by ownership.

The most fundamental aspect to the European/North American tradition/lifestyle is property.  The idea of selling one's time to buy something that will last, to which one might return to rest.  

Imagine working for 25 years to pay off something that has a value of £300 000.  That's a lot for anybody.  Anything that brings down the value of something that has already cost that much will not be viewed favourably.

There are truck stops where I live.  No problem.  It's expected, planned for, and, being private property, anybody there can be legally removed by the owner of that property in an hour or less.

Same goes for campsites.  They are also private property.  People pay to park their caravans there and leave when their time is up.  No problem.

We thrive on things being predictable, orderly, and our property rights, which do not infringe on the property rights of anybody else, being respected.  I can tell anybody on my property to leave, and as the owner, I expect my will to be enforced promptly.  It really is the most sacred natural right we have - people's homes are their castles.  

And how much does anybody own anything if trespassers, of any group, cannot be removed from it promptly?  What if non-Travellers thought that your legitimate campsite looked good and decided to move in uninvited?  I would expect your unit to react with similar hostility, and I would not blame them.
Then tell your parents to stop causing crime and trespassing if you get so upset.
